title: The Problem
& The Solution
paragraphs: Healthcare-associated infections (HAIs) affect approximately 1 in 10 patients worldwide, causing significant morbidity, mortality, and economic strain on healthcare systems. Nosocomial outbreaks driven by person-to-person transmitted pathogens such as SARS-CoV-2, Clostridioides difficile, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and MRSA generate the most acute clinical and operational crises: triggering staff shortages, ward closures, and delayed procedures. Current control measures rely on broad testing and isolation protocols, but effective intervention requires identifying the specific drivers of an outbreak: such as patient zero, superspreaders, transmission routes, and undetected or imported cases.

NosoTrack is an outbreak analytics platform that infers who infected whom in near real-time by integrating data from hospital Electronic Health Records with Bluetooth enabled contact tracing. It delivers early warnings and actionable reports, enabling hospital infection prevention teams to target interventions promptly before an outbreak escalates.

process.title: How It Works
process.subtitle: Three data streams converge into the NosoTrack pipeline — anonymised, merged, and analysed to reconstruct transmission chains and trigger real-time alerts.

cards.title: DNA Sequencing
cards.desc: Pathogen genomes are sequenced, providing phylogenetic signal for transmission linkage.

cards.title: Contact Tracing
cards.desc: Bluetooth-enabled devices record proximity events between patients and staff.

cards.title: Health Records
cards.desc: Electronic Health Records provide ward movements, test results, and clinical timelines.

anonymisation.title: Data Anonymisation
anonymisation.desc: Patient identifiers are stripped, hashed, and encrypted before any analysis — ensuring full GDPR compliance. All three data streams are processed through a secure anonymisation layer.

engine.title: NosoTrack Engine
engine.desc: Anonymised data streams are fused into a unified temporal contact network. The engine runs Bayesian phylodynamic models in near real-time, combining genomic distances, contact matrices, and ward movements to infer transmission probabilities and reconstruct who infected whom.

earlyWarning.title: Early Warning System
earlyWarning.desc: Real-time alerts and reports are dispatched to infection prevention teams before outbreaks escalate — enabling rapid containment and ward-level interventions.

title: Publications
& Software
research.intro: Novel computational methods that reconstruct who infected whom from clinical, contact, and genetic data have proven effective in guiding outbreak control across pathogens such as SARS-CoV-2, influenza, Ebola, and antimicrobial-resistant bacteria. Yet, they remain largely retrospective, with no integration into routine hospital surveillance. What is lacking is an automated system capable of deploying these models in near real-time: this is the aim of NosoTrack.

members.name: Dr Cyril Geismar
members.bio: Postdoctoral research fellow. PhD in mathematical modelling of infectious diseases at Imperial College London, focused on SARS-CoV-2 outbreak reconstruction. Executive board member and developer for the R Epidemics Consortium. Teaches outbreak analytics at Emory University and LSHTM.

members.name: Dr Thibaut Jombart
members.bio: Senior Lecturer specialising in outbreak response analytics, biostatistics, population genetics, and R programming. Lead author of outbreaker and founder of the R Epidemics Consortium. Field experience in Ebola deployments in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

members.name: Dr Anne Cori
members.bio: Senior Lecturer specialising in real-time outbreak analysis and epidemiological parameters. Lead author of EpiEstim and co-author of outbreaker. Develops statistical methods for outbreak reconstruction and rapid transmissibility assessment.

members.name: Dr Shaun Truelove
members.bio: Associate Professor focused on infectious disease dynamics and modelling for public health response and policy (COVID-19, influenza, vaccine-preventable diseases). Co-leads the US Scenario Modeling Hubs and ACCIDA, a consortium producing epidemic scenario projections and forecasts.
